This is an automatically created tracking bug!  It was created to ensure
that one or more security vulnerabilities are fixed in affected versions
of Fedora.

For comments that are specific to the vulnerability please use bugs filed
against the "Security Response" product referenced in the "Blocks" field.

For more information see:
http://fedoraproject.org/wiki/Security/TrackingBugs

When submitting as an update, use the fedpkg template provided in the next
comment(s).  This will include the bug IDs of this tracking bug as well as
the relevant top-level CVE bugs.

Please also mention the CVE IDs being fixed in the RPM changelog and the
fedpkg commit message.

NOTE: this issue affects multiple supported versions of Fedora. While only
one tracking bug has been filed, please correct all affected versions at
the same time.  If you need to fix the versions independent of each other,
you may clone this bug as appropriate.

[bug automatically created by: add-tracking-bugs]

Use the following template to for the 'fedpkg update' request to submit an
update for this issue as it contains the top-level parent bug(s) as well as
this tracking bug.  This will ensure that all associated bugs get updated
when new packages are pushed to stable.

=====

# bugfix, security, enhancement, newpackage (required)
type=security

# testing, stable
request=testing

# Bug numbers: 1234,9876
bugs=1400850,1400851,1400852,1400853,1400854,1400855,1400856,1400857,1400859,1400861,1400862,1400863,1400864,1400865,1400866,1400867,1400868,1400869,1400870,1400871,1400872,1400873,1400875,1400876,1400877,1400878,1400879,1400883

# Description of your update
notes=Security fix for CVE-2016-9651, CVE-2016-5208, CVE-2016-5207, CVE-2016-5206, CVE-2016-5205, CVE-2016-5204, CVE-2016-5209, CVE-2016-5203, CVE-2016-5210, CVE-2016-5212, CVE-2016-5211, CVE-2016-5213, CVE-2016-5214, CVE-2016-5216, CVE-2016-5215, CVE-2016-5217, CVE-2016-5218, CVE-2016-5219, CVE-2016-5221, CVE-2016-5220, CVE-2016-5222, CVE-2016-9650, CVE-2016-5223, CVE-2016-5226, CVE-2016-5225, CVE-2016-5224, CVE-2016-9652

# Enable request automation based on the stable/unstable karma thresholds
autokarma=True
stable_karma=3
unstable_karma=-3

# Automatically close bugs when this marked as stable
close_bugs=True

# Suggest that users restart after update
suggest_reboot=False

======

Additionally, you may opt to use the bodhi web interface to submit updates:

https://bodhi.fedoraproject.org/updates/new

comment.text:
Resolved the TLS Certificate transparency error.

karma: +1
Works for me on Symantec certs and in general.  Using it right now.
Resolved the TLS Certificate transparency error.
This works just fine, solves the symantec certs problem also.
This works just fine, solves the symantec certs problem also.

bugs.title: chromium shows error on ssl-sites secured by symantec certificates

bugzilla.short_desc: chromium shows error on ssl-sites secured by symantec certificates

long_desc.thetext:
Description of problem:
Since today opening ssl-sites that use certificates secured with a symantec certifcate show a certificate error:
"There are issues with the site's certificate chain (net::ERR_CERTIFICATE_TRANSPARENCY_REQUIRED)."

The certifacte has CT enabled (according to: https://knowledge.symantec.com/support/ssl-certificates-support/index?page=content&actp=CROSSLINK&id=SO28947 )

Version-Release number of selected component (if applicable):
54.0.2840.90 

How reproducible:
always

Steps to Reproduce:
Open e.g. https://amazon.com

Actual results:
certifcate error

Expected results:
no error

Additional info:
Probably related to: https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=664177

I am hitting the same problem.  This appears to be the same issue 53.x had, but punted forward a few weeks.  See comment 80 from a Googler on the issue here:

https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=664177#c80

Please update to 55.x or newer to resolve the issue.  Also affects Fedora 23 (not EOL yet!) and presumably Fedora 24.
I'm working on 55.x now. pnacl changes with every major version which slows down the process.

(In reply to Tom "spot" Callaway from comment #2)
> I'm working on 55.x now. pnacl changes with every major version which slows
> down the process.

Thanks, spot.  Is there anything I can do to help ~today (US west timezone)?  I have a little packaging experience and am familiar with C (not C++, though).

My $DAYJOB's internal websites all use Symantec certs, so this is a huge priority for me.

(In reply to Conrad Meyer from comment #3)
> (In reply to Tom "spot" Callaway from comment #2)
> > I'm working on 55.x now. pnacl changes with every major version which slows
> > down the process.
> 
> Thanks, spot.  Is there anything I can do to help ~today (US west timezone)?
> I have a little packaging experience and am familiar with C (not C++,
> though).
> 
> My $DAYJOB's internal websites all use Symantec certs, so this is a huge
> priority for me.

Thanks for the offer, but I think I've got chromium-native_client building locally now, and I am in the middle of rediffing the patches for chromium 55. I'm hopeful that I'll have good builds going before I leave for the day (US East).
Thanks, that's great to hear.
https://koji.fedoraproject.org/koji/getfile?taskID=16870811&name=build.log&offset=-4000 is looking good!
https://koji.fedoraproject.org/koji/buildinfo?buildID=825217 x86_64 works for me with Symantec certificates.

bugs.title: Chromium 55 is available

bugzilla.short_desc: Chromium 55 is available

long_desc.thetext:
I realize that this is likely a known issue, but it seems like it's disgruntling some people:

http://www.fedora-blog.de/chromium-ist-momentan-ein-sicherheitsrisiko/?pk_campaign=feed&pk_kwd=chromium-ist-momentan-ein-sicherheitsrisiko&utm_source=feedburner&utm_medium=feed&utm_campaign=feed&utm_content=Fedora-Blog.de&utm_term=Piwik
I'm working on it. Takes a bit longer to update to a major release because of pnacl.

(In reply to Tom "spot" Callaway from comment #1)
> I'm working on it. Takes a bit longer to update to a major release because
> of pnacl.

Fair enough, thanks!
